content: Renaming tag to "Reading the statement" because I don't want to be associated with aCat's "read a textbook outside of the statement" nonsense.
As per @Vry's remark, made variable names more meaningful.

@MasakiKyosuke made a fair point on chat: it's not obvious that the king of the hill's pick is known.

…so now they place them on the table.

B < 1.5×10⁶
Is there any reason for that constraint (except forcing me to zoom in as I can't read the tiny exponent)?
Testcases don't even get close to that limit.
Edit: the challenger's orbs are necessarily sparkling, so remove the glowing alternative there. Also, wedge keyword "area" in there.

When I first read the puzzle statement my first take on it was that "more interesting" was actually comparing the surface of the orbs of the challenger to the surface of the orbs of the king of the hill. I later understood that actually it was the surface of the two orbs of the challenger that were compared.
This could lead to some confusion: for instance in test case 2 printing out 2 16 is a valid  clash which at the same time is more interesting than the right answer (9 15). EDIT: The updated statement clears that up.

Edit: added a bit of formatting. Specified orb diameters are integral.

Cry for help: I'd like to include the two harder cases, but my code won't cut it. I'd like for it to remain pure bash (it's an easy puzzle after all). Any suggestion welcome!

It should be mentioned which fun solution should be returned when there are several within the range.
Typo: "kind of the hill" in input section.

Two comments on your statement:
1. Don't mix orb diameters and sizes. It confuses the user, thinking "Is the size a diameter ?". Just use "diameter" everywhere.
2. "Output => Else just print any string you want." That does not make any sense. How could this be validated with the IN/OUT system ? I am guessing this case never happens because the challenger could always return the same pick as the king of the hill.
Edit: d'uh, heterogeneous, not homo.
#nohomo
For 2, that's indeed the case as A ≤ C ≤ D ≤ B.

I love your comments.

I was about to say "but I did!" until I noticed indeed, I specified "which could" but didn't think of saying it had to be used.

And I could see no typo in neither the input section nor your comment.

…I'm tired.
Fixing, thanks!

Use this to evaluate j :

for (( j = (A+B)/2 ; nj = (2*j+j3/j/j)/3 , nj != j && j + 1 != nj; j = nj )); do :; done

I pass all the tests and your final three tests

(It's the approximation of a cubic root by newton's method with integer)

In another hand, if you want a less "magic formula" method you can use binary search to find the cubic root of j3 (perhaps more in the mood for "easy" puzzle)

I'm well aware of that statement difficulty. (FWIW, I turned my words around multiple times before publishing).

That doesn't mean it's perfect in any way yet, and I'm very open to improvements. But keep in mind I'm striving very hard for a light-worded phrasing.

"Complete but in no way redundant"

I think now the statement is clear as long as one pays attention to  details.
I do not understand the contribution of the third sentence in the examples - the clash is possible but not valid. What does that mean?
It guarantees you can fit a simplified volume in 63 bits.
…and found a proper way to define fun clashes at long last!

But B is always <= 3000, so why do you write 1.5E6 in the statement?
I know that I have to use longs anyway, I just don't see the point for writing a much higher limit in the statement than the one actually used.

I had some cases like that initially.

They're very boring, there is never a fun clash there because of the other constraint.

I'm on the fence. I could put one of those cases back in, or reduce the bound. The puzzle difficulty is in the other constraint.
Here's a flaky compromise: 10^5 because of That 2^53 bit Language, and a big&boring case.
It's euphemism for "it's invalid".

Or simply use bc to evaluate j (this passes the additional tests too):
j=$(echo "e(l($V-$i^3)/3.)+0.5" | bc -l | cut -d. -f1)
he wants a solution in pure bash
Oh, of course, yes... Anyway your solution is much more fun and faster.

It's not in the submission, but I initially tried to speed up cbrt using this http://www.nuprl.org/MathLibrary/integer_sqrt/ It wasn't enough.

It seems like bsearch is suboptimal when we know the actual polynomial shape, but then again anything that works is good for me. I'll try your thing ASAP.

Marking WIP in the meantime, I need to try that new feature too

It works and I'll take it.

It you intended to approve, ping me on the chat and I'll spare you 15XP ;)

Aïe, I found a simpler solution : 

read A B
read C D
(( V = C*C*C + D*D*D ))
(( j = B ))
for (( i = A; i <= B; i++ )); do
  (( i == C )) && continue
  (( j3 = V - i*i*i ))
  (( j3 >= i*i*i )) || break
  for (( ; j*j*j > j3; j-- )); do :; done
  if (( j*j*j == j3 )); then
    echo $i $j
    exit
  fi
done    
echo VALID
Merged. Thanks!
Nice, I would also suggest to add another small example in the statement to compare two fun clashes in terms of "interestingness" (just because it's an "Easy" puzzle).

Mmmm…
It's a good idea, but I wouldn't want to go as far as to give the actual formula :-/

Let's see if I can think of some compromise.

Niako already detected/answered your point 2. (thanks!)

About point 1, I'll update the C/D/E/F parameters that were indeed ambiguous. Thanks!
The other occurrences of "size" are in the clash qualification definitions, they're before "diameter" is even mentioned (one of them is actually explicitly a surface), and they don't introduce any ambiguity since whichever size-like measure of a sphere you use, it preserves both ordering and distinctness.

PS: I'll leave it as "increasing" instead of the more expected "non-decreasing" because a) it's real ugly b) the case where it changes something to the output won't happen
